member.name: T:Bytescout.BarCode.BarcodeWebImage
member.summary: Barcode web control that allows to generate/draw/save barcodes at server and serve it as an image.

remarks.para: To use BarcodeWebControl in a web application created without Visual Studio, you need to do two things:

item.description: First, you need to copy the Bytescout.BarCode.dll file to the bin subdirectory of your web application's virtual directory as registered with IIS. If you don't have a separate web application, you can copy it to C:\Inetpub\wwwroot\bin.

Next, you do need to modify the Web.config file in your application's virtual directory (or C:\Inetpub\wwwroot\ if you don't have a separate application), by adding,
<httpHandlers> <add verb="*" path="BarcodeHandler.aspx" type="Bytescout.BarCode.BarcodeHandler, Bytescout.BarCode"/> </httpHandlers>
inside <system.web> section.

remarks.para: Note that there's no actual file called BarcodeHandler.aspx, but you can reference it within your application as a URL and you don't need to specify any path.
For a full list of parameter names see the table below.
To use BarcodeWebControl in a web application created within Visual Studio, you need:

item.description: Add new web.config file if you don't have one.
Set up an HttpHandler in an ASP.NET web application by adding <httpHandler> section as written above.

Dag and drop BarcodeWebImage from toolbox to your web page. This will add the references to Bytescout.BarCode.dll to your project. You can fine tune added control appearance by means of Windows Forms designer.

remarks.para: Below is a table of BarcodeHandler.aspx parameters:

item.description: true if checksum should be added to barcode; otherwise, false.
true if checksum should be added to barcode caption; otherwise, false.

The barcode caption position. For possible values take a look at
The custom caption text to draw instead of the barcode encoded value.
true if to draw the barcode encoded value; otherwise, false.
The color used to draw the barcode bars and caption(s). Please use TypeConverter object for encoding. TypeConverter tc = TypeDescriptor.GetConverter(typeof(Color)); tc.ConvertToString(aForeColor);
The barcode margins. Please use following syntax for encoding: [aLeft;aTop;aRight;aBottom].
The width of the narrow bar in pixels.

member.name: T:Bytescout.BarCode.CodabarChecksumAlgorithm
member.summary: Describes all supported Codabar checksum algorithms.
member.remarks: Note that there is no checksum defined as part of the Codabar standard, but some industries (libraries, for example) have adopted their own checksum standards. Bytescout.BarCode implements two such standards.

member.name: F:Bytescout.BarCode.CodabarChecksumAlgorithm.Modulo9
member.summary:
(0) Modulo 9 checksum algorithm.
Many libraries use the following system which includes 13 digits plus a checksum;
Digit 1 indicates the type of barcode: 2 = patron, 3 = item (book)
Digits 2-5 identify the institution
The next 6 digits (00010 586) identify the individual patron or item
Digit 14 is the checksum

member.name: F:Bytescout.BarCode.CodabarChecksumAlgorithm.AiimCheckDigit
member.summary: (1) AIIM check digit calculation algorithm. This standard is recommended by AIIM.

member.name: T:Bytescout.BarCode.CodabarSpecialSymbol
member.summary: Describes special symbols of the Codabar symbology. This symbols can be set as Codabar start or termination symbols. Additional data can be encoded by the choice of start and termination characters.

member.name: F:Bytescout.BarCode.CodabarSpecialSymbol.A
member.summary: (0) The A symbol.

member.name: F:Bytescout.BarCode.CodabarSpecialSymbol.B
member.summary: (1) The B symbol.

member.name: F:Bytescout.BarCode.CodabarSpecialSymbol.C
member.summary: (2) The C symbol.

member.name: F:Bytescout.BarCode.CodabarSpecialSymbol.D
member.summary: (3) The D symbol

member.name: T:Bytescout.BarCode.Code128Alphabet
member.summary: Describes alphabet options for Code 128 symbology.

member.name: F:Bytescout.BarCode.Code128Alphabet.Auto
member.summary: (0) The alphabet to use selected automatically. Different parts of a barcode can be encoded with different alphabets. This alphabet type allows all ASCII table to be encoded with minimum output barcode width.

member.name: F:Bytescout.BarCode.Code128Alphabet.A
member.summary: (1) The A alphabet. Allows only character from NUL (ASCII 0) to '_' (ASCII 95) to be encoded.

member.name: F:Bytescout.BarCode.Code128Alphabet.B
member.summary: (2) The B alphabet. Allows only character from SPACE (ASCII 32) to DEL (ASCII 127) to be encoded.

member.name: F:Bytescout.BarCode.Code128Alphabet.C
member.summary: (3) The C alphabet. Allows only numeric values having even length to be encoded. This alphabet allows most efficient encoding of numeric values having even length.

member.name: T:Bytescout.BarCode.DataMatrixCompactionMode
member.summary: Describes all possible compaction (encoding) modes for DataMatrix symbology.

member.name: F:Bytescout.BarCode.DataMatrixCompactionMode.Auto
member.summary: (-1) Library will choose best compaction mode (aim is to produce shortest encoded byte string).

member.name: F:Bytescout.BarCode.DataMatrixCompactionMode.Ascii
member.summary: (0) ASCII compaction mode. Sort of 'general purpose' mode. One encoded symbol produced from: 1/2 of source symbol for ASCII characters with code from 128 to 255, 1 source symbol for ASCII characters with code from 0 to 127, 2 source symbols for ASCII digits.

member.name: F:Bytescout.BarCode.DataMatrixCompactionMode.C40
member.summary: (1) C40 compaction mode. Best for upper-case alphanumeric strings. One encoded symbol produced from 1 and 1/2 of source symbols.

member.name: F:Bytescout.BarCode.DataMatrixCompactionMode.Text
member.summary: (2) TEXT compaction mode. Best for lower-case alphanumeric strings. One encoded symbol produced from 1 and 1/2 of source symbols.

member.name: F:Bytescout.BarCode.DataMatrixCompactionMode.X12
member.summary: (3) X12 compaction mode. Useful for encoding symbols from " 0123456789ABCDEFGHIJKLMNOPQRSTUVWXYZ\r*>" range. One encoded symbol produced from 1 and 1/2 of source symbols.

member.name: F:Bytescout.BarCode.DataMatrixCompactionMode.Edifact
member.summary: (4) EDIFACT compaction mode. Best for ASCII charcters with codes from 32 to 94. One encoded symbol produced from 1 and 1/3 of source symbols.

member.name: F:Bytescout.BarCode.DataMatrixCompactionMode.Binary
member.summary: (5) BINARY (or BASE256) compaction mode. Can encoded all ASCII symbols. One encoded symbol produced from one source symbol.

member.name: T:Bytescout.BarCode.DataMatrixSize
member.summary: Describes all possible matrix sizes for DataMatrix symbology.

member.name: F:Bytescout.BarCode.DataMatrixSize.AutoSquareSize
member.summary: (0) Library will choose smallest possible square matrix size.

member.name: F:Bytescout.BarCode.DataMatrixSize.AutoSize
member.summary: (1) Library will choose smallest possible matrix size.

member.name: F:Bytescout.BarCode.DataMatrixSize.Size8x18
member.summary: (2) 8 rows x 18 columns. 1 data region.

member.name: F:Bytescout.BarCode.DataMatrixSize.Size8x32
member.summary: (3) 8 rows x 32 columns. 2 data regions.

member.name: F:Bytescout.BarCode.DataMatrixSize.Size10x10
member.summary: (4) 10 rows x 10 columns. 1 data region.

member.name: F:Bytescout.BarCode.DataMatrixSize.Size12x12
member.summary: (5) 12 rows x 12 columns. 1 data region.

member.summary: (6) 12 rows x 26 columns. 1 data region.

member.name: F:Bytescout.BarCode.DataMatrixSize.Size12x36
member.summary: (7) 12 rows x 36 columns. 2 vertical data regions.

member.name: F:Bytescout.BarCode.DataMatrixSize.Size14x14
member.summary: (8) 14 rows x 14 columns. 1 data region.

member.name: F:Bytescout.BarCode.DataMatrixSize.Size16x16
member.summary: (9) 16 rows x 16 columns. 1 data region.

member.name: F:Bytescout.BarCode.DataMatrixSize.Size16x36
member.summary: (10) 16 rows x 36 columns. 2 vertical data regions.

member.name: F:Bytescout.BarCode.DataMatrixSize.Size16x48

member.name: F:Bytescout.BarCode.DataMatrixSize.Size18x18

member.name: M:Bytescout.BarCode.IBarcode.AddDecorationImage(System.String,System.Int32)
member.summary: Add decorative image to draw in the center of the barcode. (!) Supported with QR Code only.
member.remarks: Note, the embedded image damages the barcode, but the QR Code's error correction algorithm makes it possible to decode the damaged barcode if the damage doesn't exceed 7-30% of barcode square (depending on the error correction level). See and . It's recommended to generate the QR Code with highest error correction level and check the barcode is still decodable after image applying. To read the barcode you can use ByteScout Barcode Reader SDK: https://bytescout.com/products/developer/barcodereadersdk/bytescoutbarcodereadersdk.html
member.param: Image to add to barcode.
Scale of the image square relatively to the barcode square, in percents. Recommended is 15 percents with the highest error correction level. Set -1 to disable the scaling.

member.name: M:Bytescout.BarCode.IBarcode.AddDecorationImage(System.Drawing.Image,System.Int32)
member.summary: Add decorative image to draw in the center of the barcode. (!) Supported with QR Code only.
member.remarks: Note, the embedded image damages the barcode, but the QR Code's error correction algorithm makes it possible to decode the damaged barcode if the damage doesn't exceed 7-30% of barcode square (depending on the error correction level). See and . It's recommended to generate the QR Code with highest error correction level and check the barcode is still decodable after image applying. To read the barcode you can use ByteScout Barcode Reader SDK: https://bytescout.com/products/developer/barcodereadersdk/bytescoutbarcodereadersdk.html
member.param: Image to add to barcode.
Scale of the image square relatively to the barcode square, in percents. Recommended is 15 percents with the highest error correction level. Set -1 to disable the scaling.

member.name: T:Bytescout.BarCode.TelepenAlphabet
member.summary: Describes alphabet options for Telepen symbology.

member.name: F:Bytescout.BarCode.TelepenAlphabet.ASCII
member.summary: (0) The alphabet to use ASCII chars (encoded as string) All characters are encoded as ASCII characters.

member.name: F:Bytescout.BarCode.TelepenAlphabet.Numeric
member.summary: (1) The Numeric alphabet. Works when input value contains numbers only and makes smaller size barcodes by packing each number Input string should contain numbers only.

member.name: F:Bytescout.BarCode.TelepenAlphabet.Auto
member.summary: (2) Mixed alphabet. Automatically selects appropriate alphabet (ASCII or Numeric) for different parts of barcode. WARNING: Not supported by some hardware barcode readers manufacturers

member.name: F:Bytescout.BarCode.PZNType.PZN8
member.summary: New PZN8 standard with 7 significant digits. Supercedes PZN7 since 2013-01-01. Default.

member.name: T:Bytescout.BarCode.PDF417CompactionMode
member.summary: Describes all possible compaction (encoding) modes for PDF417 symbology.

member.name: F:Bytescout.BarCode.PDF417CompactionMode.Auto
member.summary: (-1) Library will choose best compaction mode (aim is to produce shortest encoded byte string).

member.name: F:Bytescout.BarCode.PDF417CompactionMode.Binary
member.summary: (0) Binary compaction mode. Can encode any ASCII symbol.

member.name: F:Bytescout.BarCode.PDF417CompactionMode.Text
member.summary: (1) Text compaction mode (allows optimized text encoding)

member.name: F:Bytescout.BarCode.PDF417CompactionMode.Numeric
member.summary: (2) Numeric compaction mode (allows optimized encoding of numbers)

member.name: T:Bytescout.BarCode.PDF417ErrorCorrectionLevel
member.summary: Describes all possible error correction levels for PDF417 symbology.
member.remarks: When error correction level set to Auto, library will try to use best possible error correction level. Error correction is done by adding extra symbols to barcode. Higher error correction level adds more extra symbols and thus shortens possible length of string to encode.

member.name: F:Bytescout.BarCode.PDF417ErrorCorrectionLevel.Auto
member.summary: (-1) Library will choose best possible error correction level.

member.name: F:Bytescout.BarCode.PDF417ErrorCorrectionLevel.Level0
member.summary: (0) Level 0 error correction. 2 extra symbols will be added to encoded data.

member.name: F:Bytescout.BarCode.PDF417ErrorCorrectionLevel.Level1
member.summary: (1) Level 1 error correction. 4 extra symbols will be added to encoded data.

member.name: F:Bytescout.BarCode.PDF417ErrorCorrectionLevel.Level2
member.summary: (2) Level 2 error correction. 8 extra symbols will be added to encoded data.

member.name: F:Bytescout.BarCode.PDF417ErrorCorrectionLevel.Level3
member.summary: (3) Level 3 error correction. 16 extra symbols will be added to encoded data.

member.name: F:Bytescout.BarCode.PDF417ErrorCorrectionLevel.Level4
member.summary: (4) Level 4 error correction. 32 extra symbols will be added to encoded data.

member.name: F:Bytescout.BarCode.PDF417ErrorCorrectionLevel.Level5
member.summary: (5) Level 5 error correction. 64 extra symbols will be added to encoded data.

member.name: F:Bytescout.BarCode.PDF417ErrorCorrectionLevel.Level6
member.summary: (6) Level 6 error correction. 128 extra symbols will be added to encoded data.

member.name: F:Bytescout.BarCode.PDF417ErrorCorrectionLevel.Level7
member.summary: (7) Level 7 error correction. 256 extra symbols will be added to encoded data.

member.name: F:Bytescout.BarCode.PDF417ErrorCorrectionLevel.Level8
member.summary: (8) Level 8 error correction. 512 extra symbols will be added to encoded data.

member.name: T:Bytescout.BarCode.QREncodeHint

member.name: F:Bytescout.BarCode.QREncodeHint.Mode8
member.summary: (0) All of non-alphanumerical characters will be encoded as is. This is default mode.

member.name: F:Bytescout.BarCode.QREncodeHint.Kanji
member.summary: (1) Kanji/Kana characters will be encoded as Shif-JIS characters.

member.name: T:Bytescout.BarCode.QRErrorCorrectionLevel
member.summary: Level of error correction in QR Code symbols

member.name: F:Bytescout.BarCode.QRErrorCorrectionLevel.Low
member.summary: (0) Lowest error correction level (Approx. 7% of codewords can be restored).

member.name: F:Bytescout.BarCode.QRErrorCorrectionLevel.Medium
member.summary: (1) Medium error correction level (Approx. 15% of codewords can be restored).

member.name: F:Bytescout.BarCode.QRErrorCorrectionLevel.Quarter
member.summary: (2) Quarter error correction level (Approx. 25% of codewords can be restored).

member.name: F:Bytescout.BarCode.QRErrorCorrectionLevel.High
member.summary: (3) Highest error correction level (Approx. 30% of codewords can be restored).

member.name: P:Bytescout.BarCode.SymbologyOptions.TextEncodingCodePage
member.summary:
Gets or sets the character encoding of barcode value. Default is - the default encoding on your computer. You may override this value like:
barcode.Options.TextEncodingCodePage = 1250; // to use German locale to decode text
.NET interface: please use property instead Some of available code pages are listed below for your reference:
Name CodePage EncodingName shift_jis 932 Japanese (Shift-JIS) windows-1250 1250 Central European (Windows) windows-1251 1251 Cyrillic (Windows) Windows-1252 1252 Western European (Windows) windows-1253 1253 Greek (Windows) windows-1254 1254 Turkish (Windows) csISO2022JP 50221 Japanese (JIS-Allow 1 byte Kana) iso-2022-kr 50225 Korean (ISO)

member.name: T:Bytescout.BarCode.SymbologyType
member.summary: Describes all supported barcode symbologies (types).

member.name: F:Bytescout.BarCode.SymbologyType.Code128
member.summary: (0) Code 128 barcode (Also known as Code-128). It is a very effective, high-density symbology which permits the encoding of alphanumeric (subject to alphabet selection) data. Code 128 is a very dense code, used extensively worldwide.

member.name: F:Bytescout.BarCode.SymbologyType.Code39
member.summary: (1) Code 39 barcode (Also known as USD-3, Code 3 of 9, LOGMARS and in extended mode also know as Code39Extended, Code 39 Full ASCII mode). Code 39 symbology allows all ASCII symbols to be encoded in extended mode or symbols from this string "0123456789ABCDEFGHIJKLMNOPQRSTUVWXYZ-. $/+%" in standard mode. This symbology used for example by U.S. Government and military, required for DoD applications.

member.name: F:Bytescout.BarCode.SymbologyType.Postnet
member.summary: (2) Postnet barcode. This symbology usually gets printed by U.S. Post Office on envelopes. Postnet symbology allows only numeric values to be encoded. The bar code itself can encode either a standard 5-digit Zip Code, a Zip+4 code, or a full 11-point delivery point code.

member.name: F:Bytescout.BarCode.SymbologyType.UPCA
member.summary: (3) UPC-A barcode (Also known as UPCA). Used with consumer products in U.S. UPC-A symbology allows only numeric values to be encoded.

member.name: F:Bytescout.BarCode.SymbologyType.EAN8
member.summary: (4) EAN-8 barcode (GTIN-8). This symbology is a short version of EAN-13 that is intended to be used on packaging which would be otherwise too small to use one of the other versions. Used with consumer products internationally. EAN-8 symbology allows only numeric values to be encoded.

member.name: F:Bytescout.BarCode.SymbologyType.ISBN
member.summary: (5) ISBN Number encoded as EAN-13 barcode.

member.name: F:Bytescout.BarCode.SymbologyType.Codabar
member.summary: (6) Codabar barcode (Also known as Ames Code, USD-4, NW-7, Code 2 of 7). Codabar symbology allows only symbols from this string '0123456789-$:/.+' to be encoded. This symbology used for example in libraries and blood banks.

member.name: F:Bytescout.BarCode.SymbologyType.I2of5
member.summary: (7) Interleaved 2 of 5 barcode (Also know as Code 2 of 5 Interleaved). Interleaved 2 of 5 symbology allows only numeric values to be encoded. This symbology is used primarily in the distribution and warehouse industry.

member.name: F:Bytescout.BarCode.SymbologyType.Code93
member.summary: (8) Code 93 barcode (Also known as USS-93, Code93 and in extended mode also known as Code93Extended, Code 93 Full ASCII mode). Code 93 symbology allows all ASCII symbols to be encoded in extended mode or symbols from this string "0123456789ABCDEFGHIJKLMNOPQRSTUVWXYZ-. $/+%" in standard mode. This symbology was designed to complement and improve upon Code 39 symbology. Code 93 produces denser code than that of Code 39.

member.name: F:Bytescout.BarCode.SymbologyType.EAN13
member.summary: (9) EAN-13 barcode (GTIN-13). Used with consumer products internationally. EAN-13 symbology allows only numeric values to be encoded.

member.name: F:Bytescout.BarCode.SymbologyType.JAN13
member.summary: (10) JAN-13 barcode (Also known as JAN codes). This symbology is mostly the same as EAN-13 symbology, but used in Japan. JAN stands for Japanese Numbering Authority. First two digits of JAN-13 symbology are always "49".

member.name: F:Bytescout.BarCode.SymbologyType.Bookland
member.summary: (11) Bookland barcode. This symbology is mostly the same as EAN-13 symbology, but used exclusively with books. First three digits of Bookland symbology are always "978" the rest of code is a ISBN number without embedded hyphens and ISBN check digit.

member.name: F:Bytescout.BarCode.SymbologyType.UPCE
member.summary: (12) UPC-E barcode (Also known as UPCE). This symbology is zero-suppression version of UPC-A. It is intended to be used on packaging which would be otherwise too small to use one of the other versions. The code is smaller because it drops out zeros which would otherwise occur in a symbol. Used with consumer products in U.S. UPC-E symbology allows only numeric values to be encoded.

member.name: F:Bytescout.BarCode.SymbologyType.PDF417
member.summary: (13) PDF417 symbology. This symbology is heavily used in the parcel industry. The PDF417 symbology can encode a vast amount of data into a small space. This symbology allows a maximum data size of 1850 text characters, or 2710 digits.

member.name: F:Bytescout.BarCode.SymbologyType.PDF417Truncated
member.summary: (14) PDF417 Truncated symbology. This symbology is a truncted (right column is missing) or compact version of PDF417 symbology.

member.name: F:Bytescout.BarCode.SymbologyType.DataMatrix
member.summary: (15) Data Matrix symbology. The most popular application for Data Matrix is marking small items. The Data Matrix can encode text and raw data. Usual data size is from a few bytes up to 2 kilobytes.

member.name: F:Bytescout.BarCode.SymbologyType.QRCode
member.summary: (16) QR Code symbology. QR Code initially was used for tracking parts in vehicle manufacturing, but now QR Codes used in a much broader context, including both commercial tracking applications and convenience-oriented applications aimed at mobile phone users (known as mobile tagging).

member.name: F:Bytescout.BarCode.SymbologyType.Aztec
member.summary: (17) Aztec Code symbology. An Aztec code barcode is used by Deutsche Bahn, Trenitalia and by Swiss Federal Railways for tickets sold online and printed out by customers. The Aztec Code has been selected by the airline industry (IATA's BCBP standard) for the electronic boarding passes.

member.name: F:Bytescout.BarCode.SymbologyType.Planet
member.summary: (18) PLANET (The Postal Alpha Numeric Encoding Technique) barcode is used by the United States Postal Service to identify and track pieces of mail during delivery - the Post Office's "CONFIRM" services.

member.name: F:Bytescout.BarCode.SymbologyType.EAN128
member.summary: (19) EAN128 symbology (Also known as EAN-128, EAN-14, Shipping Container Code, UCC-14, DUN-14 (Distribution Unit Number), SSC-14, GS1-128, UCC-128, UCC/EAN-128. This symbology was developed to provide a worldwide format and standard for exchanging common data between companies.

member.name: F:Bytescout.BarCode.SymbologyType.GS1_128
member.summary: (20) GS1-128 symbology (new name for EAN128 symbology)

member.name: F:Bytescout.BarCode.SymbologyType.USPSSackLabel
member.summary: (21) USPS Sack Label symbology (Also known as USPS 25 Sack Label). This is in fact Interleaved 2 of 5 symbology with exactly 8 digits encoded: 5-digit Zip Code (the sack destination) and a 3-digit content identifier number(CIN).

member.name: F:Bytescout.BarCode.SymbologyType.USPSTrayLabel
member.summary: (22) USPS Tray Label symbology (Also known as USPS 25 Tray Label). This is in fact Interleaved 2 of 5 symbology with exactly 10 digits encoded: 5-digit Zip Code (the tray destination) and a 3-digit content identifier number(CIN), and a 2-digit USPS processing code.

member.name: F:Bytescout.BarCode.SymbologyType.DeutschePostIdentcode
member.summary: (23) Deutsche Post Identcode (Also known as Deutsche Post AG IdentCode, German Postal 2 of 5 IdentCode, Deutsche Frachtpost IdentCode, IdentCode, Deutsche Post AG (DHL). This symbology is used by German Post (Deutsche Post AG) (Deutsche Frachtpost). The barcode contains a tracking number providing an identification of the customer (sender) and the mail piece. The value to encode length is fixed to 11 digits. The value to encode must have the following structure: 2 digits for ID of primary distribution center, 3 digits for Customer ID, and 6 digits for Mailing number.

member.name: F:Bytescout.BarCode.SymbologyType.DeutschePostLeitcode
member.summary: (24) Deutsche Post Leitcode (Also known as German Postal 2 of 5 LeitCode, LeitCode, CodeLeitcode, Deutsche Post AG (DHL)). This symbology is used by German Post (Deutsche Post AG) (Deutsche Frachtpost). The barcode gives an indication of the destination. The value to encode length is fixed to 13 digits. The value to encode must have the following structure: 5 digits for Postal Code (Postleitzahl, PLZ), 3 digits for Street ID/number, 3 digits for House number, and 2 digits for Product code.

member.name: F:Bytescout.BarCode.SymbologyType.Numly
member.summary: (25) Numly barcode (Also known as ESN, Electronic Serial Number). This barcode is a unique identifier that allows an author or publisher to assign to content and track licensing of each id assignment. Numly Numbers are useful if you wish to identify each electronic distributed copy of any form of electronic media. Numly Numbers can also act a third-party content submission time stamps to aid in copyright proving instances and emails. The length of value to encode is fixed to 19 digits.

member.name: F:Bytescout.BarCode.SymbologyType.PZN
member.summary: (26) PZN barcode (Also known as Pharma-Zentral-Nummer, Pharmazentralnummer, Code PZN, CodePZN, Pharma Zentral Nummer). This symbology is used for distribution of pharmaceutical / health care products in Germany. The specification of this application is maintained at Informationsstelle fr Arzneispezialitten GmbH (IFA). The length of value to encode is 6 digits.

member.name: F:Bytescout.BarCode.SymbologyType.OpticalProduct
member.summary: (27) Optical Product Code (Also known as OPC, Vision Council of America OPC, VCA BarCode, VCA OPC) symbology. This symbology is used for marking retail optical products. The OPC is a 9-digit, numeric code that identifies the product and the manufacturer. The structure of the OPC code is the following: 5 digits for Manufacturer Identification Number assigned by the Optical Product Code Council, Inc., 4 digits for Item Identification Number assigned and controlled by the optical manufacturer.

member.name: F:Bytescout.BarCode.SymbologyType.SwissPostParcel
member.summary: (28) Swiss Post Parcel (Also known as SwissPost Parcel Barcode, Switzerland Post Parcel Barcode, Swiss PostParcel Barcode) symbology. This symbology is used by Swiss Post. It identifies each parcel and serves as a means of verifying mailing and delivery and checking the service offering. All parcels must have a unique barcode. The barcode is the requirement for automated processing. The barcode serves as a means of identifying the item. The structure of the Swiss Post Parcel barcode is 18 numeric digits: 2 digits for Swiss Post reference, 8 digits for Franking license number, and 8 digits for Item number.

member.name: F:Bytescout.BarCode.SymbologyType.RoyalMail
member.summary: (29) Royal Mail barcode (Also known as RMS4CC, RoyalMail4SCC, Royal Mail 4-State, British Royal Mail 4-State Customer Code, 4-State). This symbology was created for automated mail sorting. It normally codes the postcode and the house or mailbox number in a machine readable format. The contents of the code may vary in different countries. This symbology encodes alpha-numeric characters (0-9, A-Z).

member.name: F:Bytescout.BarCode.SymbologyType.DutchKix
member.summary: (30) Dutch KIX barcode (Also known as Royal TNT Post Kix, Dutch KIX 4-State Barcode, Kix Barcode, TPG KIX, Klantenindex Barcode, TPGPOST KIX). This symbology is used by Royal Dutch TPG Post (Netherlands) for Postal code and automatic mail sorting. It provides information about the address of the receiver. This symbology encodes alpha-numeric characters (0-9, A-Z).

member.name: F:Bytescout.BarCode.SymbologyType.SingaporePostalCode
member.summary: (31) Singapore 4-State Postal Code barcode (Also known as Singapore 4-State Postal, SingPost 4-State, SingPost Barcode, Singapore 4-State Code). This Symbology is used by Singapore Post (SingPost) for Postal code and automatic mail sorting. Such barcode provides information about the address of the receiver. This symbology encodes alpha-numeric characters (0-9, A-Z).

member.name: F:Bytescout.BarCode.SymbologyType.EAN2
member.summary: (32) The EAN-2 (Also known as EAN/2 and EAN 2) is a supplement to the EAN-13 and UPC-A barcodes. It is often used on magazines and periodicals to indicate an issue number.

member.name: F:Bytescout.BarCode.SymbologyType.EAN5
member.summary: (33) The EAN-5 (Also known as EAN/5 and EAN 5) is a supplement to EAN-13 and UPC-A barcodes. It is often used to give a suggestion for the price of the book.

member.name: F:Bytescout.BarCode.SymbologyType.EAN14
member.summary: (34) The EAN14 symbology is used for traded goods.

member.name: F:Bytescout.BarCode.SymbologyType.MacroPDF417
member.summary: (35) The Macro version of PDF417 Symbology.

member.name: F:Bytescout.BarCode.SymbologyType.MicroPDF417
member.summary: (36) The Micro version of PDF417 Symbology.

member.name: F:Bytescout.BarCode.SymbologyType.GS1_DataMatrix
member.summary: (37) GS1 DataMatrix is a 2D (two-dimensional) barcode that holds large amounts of data in a relatively small space. These barcodes are used primarily in aerospace, pharmaceuticals, medical device manufacturing, and by the U.S. Department of Defense to add visibility to the value chain. GS1 DataMatrix can be used for parts that need to be tracked in the manufacturing process because the barcode allows users to encode a variety of information related to the product, such as date or lot number. They are not intended to be used on items that pass through retail point-of-sale (POS).

member.name: F:Bytescout.BarCode.SymbologyType.Telepen
member.summary: (38) The Telepen symbology. This symbology is used in many countries and very widely in the UK. Most Universities and other academic libraries use Telepen, as do many public libraries. Other users include the motor industry, Ministry of Defence and innumerable well-known organisations for many different applications.

member.name: F:Bytescout.BarCode.SymbologyType.IntelligentMail
member.summary: (39) The Intelligent Mail Barcode symbology. This symbology is used in the USPS mailstream. It is also known as the USPS OneCode Solution or USPS 4-State Customer Barcode (abbreviated 4CB, 4-CB, or USPS4CB)

member.name: F:Bytescout.BarCode.SymbologyType.GS1_DataBar_Omnidirectional
member.summary: (40) The GS1 DataBar Omnidirectional symbology.

member.name: F:Bytescout.BarCode.SymbologyType.GS1_DataBar_Truncated
member.summary: (41) The GS1 DataBar Truncated symbology.

member.name: F:Bytescout.BarCode.SymbologyType.GS1_DataBar_Stacked
member.summary: (42) The GS1 DataBar Stacked symbology.

member.name: F:Bytescout.BarCode.SymbologyType.GS1_DataBar_Stacked_Omnidirectional
member.summary: (43) The GS1 DataBar Stacked Omnidirectional symbology.

member.name: F:Bytescout.BarCode.SymbologyType.GS1_DataBar_Limited
member.summary: (44) The GS1 DataBar Limited symbology.

member.name: F:Bytescout.BarCode.SymbologyType.GS1_DataBar_Expanded
member.summary: (45) The GS1 DataBar Expanded symbology.

member.name: F:Bytescout.BarCode.SymbologyType.GS1_DataBar_Expanded_Stacked
member.summary: (46) The GS1 DataBar Expanded Stacked symbology.

member.name: F:Bytescout.BarCode.SymbologyType.MaxiCode
member.summary: (47) The MaxiCode symbology.

member.name: F:Bytescout.BarCode.SymbologyType.Plessey
member.summary: (48) The Plessey Code symbology. This symbology is used primarily in libraries and for retail grocery shelf marking.

member.name: F:Bytescout.BarCode.SymbologyType.MSI
member.summary: (49) The MSI (also known as Modified Plessey) symbology. This symbology is used primarily for inventory control, marking storage containers and shelves in warehouse environments.

member.name: F:Bytescout.BarCode.SymbologyType.ITF14
member.summary: (50) The ITF-14 (GTIN-14, UCC-14) symbology. ITF-14 is the GS1 implementation of an Interleaved 2 of 5 bar code to encode a Global Trade Item Number. ITF-14 symbols are generally used on a packaging step of products. The ITF-14 always encodes 14 digits.

member.name: F:Bytescout.BarCode.SymbologyType.GTIN12
member.summary: (51) The GTIN-12 (12-digit UPC-A) symbology. GTIN-12 is a 12-digit number used primarily in North America.

member.name: F:Bytescout.BarCode.SymbologyType.GTIN8
member.summary: (52) The GTIN-8 (EAN-8, UCC-8): this is an 8-digit number used predominately outside of North America.

member.name: F:Bytescout.BarCode.SymbologyType.GTIN13
member.summary: (53) The GTIN-13 (EAN-13, UCC-13): this is an 13-digit number used predominately outside of North America.

member.name: F:Bytescout.BarCode.SymbologyType.GTIN14
member.summary: (54) The GTIN-14 (ITF-14, EAN-14, UCC-14) symbology. GTIN-14 is the GS1 implementation of an Interleaved 2 of 5 bar code to encode a Global Trade Item Number. GTIN-14 symbols are generally used on a packaging step of products. The GTIN-14 always encodes 14 digits.

member.name: F:Bytescout.BarCode.SymbologyType.GS1_QRCode
member.summary: (55) GS1 QRCode

member.name: F:Bytescout.BarCode.SymbologyType.PharmaCode
member.summary: (56) Pharma Code
